answer_html: and hence every nonzero vector v is an eigenvector.
answer_latex: and hence every \textbf{nonzero} vector \emph{v} is an eigenvector.
hints_html: Eigenvalues are the roots of the characteristic polynomial given by \(\det(A-\lambda I)\). For the eigenvectors, observe what happens when you take a vector v and multiply it by your matrix.
hints_latex:
Eigenvalues are the roots of the characteristic polynomial given by
$\det(A-\lambda I)$. For the eigenvectors, observe what happens when you
take a vector \emph{v} and multiply it by your matrix.
hints_raw: Eigenvalues are the roots of the characteristic polynomial given by <math>\det(A-\lambda I)</math>. For the eigenvectors, observe what happens when you take a vector ''v'' and multiply it by your matrix.
question: A 25
sols_html:
Notice that

\(\det(A-I\lambda) = \det\left( \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} -\begin{bmatrix} \lambda & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & \lambda \end{bmatrix} \right) = -\lambda^{3}\)

and the roots of this polynomial are \(\lambda =0\). This is a triple root and so this is the only eigenvalue. Next, for any vector v, we have

\(Av = 0 = 0v\)

and hence every nonzero vector v is an eigenvector.
sols_latex:
Notice that

$\det(A-I\lambda)
= \det\left( \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 
\end{bmatrix}
-\begin{bmatrix}
\lambda & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \lambda & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \lambda 
\end{bmatrix}
\right)
= -\lambda^{3}$

and the roots of this polynomial are $\lambda =0$. This is a triple root
and so this is the only eigenvalue. Next, for any vector \emph{v}, we
have

$Av = 0 = 0v$

and hence every \textbf{nonzero} vector \emph{v} is an eigenvector.
sols_raw:
Notice that 

<math>\det(A-I\lambda)
= \det\left( \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 
\end{bmatrix}
-\begin{bmatrix}
\lambda & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \lambda & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \lambda 
\end{bmatrix}
\right)
= -\lambda^{3}
</math>

and the roots of this polynomial are <math>\lambda =0 </math>. This is a triple root and so this is the only eigenvalue. Next, for any vector ''v'', we have

<math> Av = 0 = 0v </math>

and hence every '''nonzero''' vector ''v'' is an eigenvector.
statement_html:
What are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix A below?

\(A = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\)
statement_latex:
What are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix \emph{A} below?

$A = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 
\end{bmatrix}$
statement_raw:
What are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix ''A'' below?

<math>
A = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 
\end{bmatrix}
</math>
